author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Francia Márquez, activista y ex empleada doméstica, es la vicepresidenta de Colombia
description: Márquez llamó la atención hacia las disparidades del país y abrió una franca discusión nacional sobre el racismo y el clasismo, asuntos que rara vez se tocan en los círculos políticos del poder.
content: Por primera vez en la historia de Colombia, una mujer afrocolombiana está cerca de la cima del poder ejecutivo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: A French nuclear crisis frustrates Europe’s push to quit Russian energy.
description: PARIS — As the European Union moves to cut ties to Russian oil and gas in the wake of Moscow’s war on Ukraine, France has been betting on its nuclear plants to weather a looming energy crunch. Nuclear power provides about 70 percent of France’s electricity, a bigger share than any other country in the world.
content: PARIS — As the European Union moves to cut ties to Russian oil and gas in the wake of Moscow’s war on Ukraine, France has been betting on its nuclear plants to weather a looming energy crunch. Nuclear power provides about 70 percent of France’s electricity, a bigger share than any other country in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff
title: Discovering Black Family Heirlooms and the Stories Behind Them
description: The Narrative Projects team asked photographers to document objects that represented their family histories.
content: Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff is an editor on Narrative Projects who worked on “Heirlooms, Redefined.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Two Cast Members of ‘The Chosen One’ on Netflix Killed in Accident
description: The accident happened in transit to a local airport in Baja California Sur in Mexico. Six other cast and crew members were injured, Netflix confirmed.
content: Two cast members of the Netflix show “The Chosen One” died after an accident on Thursday in Baja California Sur, Mexico, that left six other cast and crew members injured, Netflix said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky and Genevieve Glatsky
title: Scenes from the polls as Rodolfo Hernández and Gustavo Petro cast their ballots.
description: Rodolfo Hernández, a construction magnate-and former mayor who has emerged as a surprise candidate in Colombia’s presidential election, has been largely absent from public life in recent weeks.
content: Rodolfo Hernández, a construction magnate-and former mayor who has emerged as a surprise candidate in Colombia’s presidential election, has been largely absent from public life in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: The U.S. Open’s Vexing Host Entertains a Promising Upstart
description: Tied for the tournament lead entering Sunday, Will Zalatoris will get another shot at his first major win after surviving a perilous third round.
content: BROOKLINE, Mass. — The U.S. Open usually waits until the final day of its 72-hole crucible to toy with the world’s best golfers. But perhaps in tribute to the venerable history of this year’s host, vexing conditions — blustery winds, thick rough and fast greens — began to crush the wills and sap the souls of the players 24 hours early at the Country Club outside Boston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: Tattoo Artists Face a Grayer Palette in Europe
description: The E.U. has prohibited some pigments, deeming them potentially hazardous to humans. Artists and manufacturers around the world are struggling to find replacements.
content: Along a bare torso and down a thigh, the sun glints through ocean waters and bathes coral and fish in aqueous light. On a lower leg, vivid frogs tense, as if preparing to jump from dewy leaves. A mischievous child with twinkling blue eyes stares out from an inner bicep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: National Juneteenth Museum Takes Shape in Fort Worth
description: The brainchild of Opal Lee, the institution will be part of an economic development project aimed at revitalizing the city’s Historic Southside neighborhood.
content: In 2016, at 89, Opal Lee walked from her home in Fort Worth to Washington, D.C., to help get Juneteenth made a federal holiday, which it finally was in 2021. And for nearly 20 years, she has operated a modest Juneteenth Museum in a property on Rosedale Street, which also served as a filming location for the 2020 movie “Miss Juneteenth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Francia Márquez — a former housekeeper and activist — is Colombia’s first Black vice president.
description: Ms. Márquez’s biting analysis of social disparities cracked open a discussion about race and class in a manner rarely heard in the country’s powerful political circles.
content: For the first time in Colombia’s history, a Black woman is close to the top of the executive branch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘God’s Fool’ Review: A Singing, Beat Poet Saint
description: In Martha Clarke’s piece about St. Francis of Assisi, at La MaMa’s Ellen Stewart Theater, the song carries the dance.
content: The life of St. Francis of Assisi was a dramatic one. The child of a wealthy Italian merchant, he had a 12th-century playboy youth, went to war and spent a year in captivity. He had mystical visions, stole from his disapproving father to give to the church and devoted himself to a life of poverty in imitation of Christ, founding a religious order. He saw God in nature, thanking the sun, preaching to birds — setting an example of equality and ecology followed by many, including the current Pope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Pink Slip Dresses and Purple Tuxedos
description: The best outfits from the Apollo benefit, Tribeca Film Festival dinner and Opening Ceremony party.
content: The stock market may be down, but charities are still raising funds. The Apollo Theater reaped $3.7 million at its spring benefit on Monday, including a $500,000 surprise gift from the night’s honoree, Tyler Perry. Guests, some who wore traditional African garb, enjoyed performances by the Roots, followed by a party down the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: New Yorkers Honor a Thriving Black Village Displaced by Central Park
description: On Juneteenth, a commemoration tells the story of Seneca Village, which was pushed out when the park was created in the 1850s.
content: Before the Civil War, a predominantly Black community flourished in Seneca Village, on the land that is now Central Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: A Rebranded ‘92NY’ Is Getting a Long-Awaited Renovation
description: After a lengthy closure during the pandemic, the Upper East Side institution has begun the first major phase of a $200 million plan to redevelop its campus.
content: Changes are afoot at the 92nd Street Y. For starters, that’s not technically its name anymore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Gov. Hochul’s Second-in-Command Faces Sharp Challenge From the Left
description: Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado faces two rivals in New York’s June 28 primary, including Ana María Archila, an activist who first won attention during Justice Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearing.
content: With a little more than a week until Primary Day in New York, the Democratic Party’s left wing is focused on a contentious statewide race shaped by issues of ideology, ethnicity and the influence of money and lobbying in Albany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: New York Firefighter Dies in North Carolina After Tree Falls on Car
description: An accident during a windstorm at the Biltmore Estate killed Casey Skudin, a decorated firefighter who had been driving with his family.
content: A decorated New York firefighter was killed in a freakish accident at a tourist attraction in North Carolina after a tree fell on the S.U.V. that he and his family had been riding in, according to his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Why a Rhodes Scholar’s Ambition Led Her to a Job at Starbucks
description: Jaz Brisack became a barista for the same reasons that talented young people have long chosen their career paths: a mix of idealism and ambition.
content: Most weekend mornings, Jaz Brisack gets up around 5, wills her semiconscious body into a Toyota Prius and winds her way through Buffalo, to the Starbucks on Elmwood Avenue. After a supervisor unlocks the door, she clocks in, checks herself for Covid symptoms and helps get the store ready for customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: At Cliburn Competition, Pianists From South Korea, Russia and Ukraine Triumph
description: The war in Ukraine loomed over the prestigious contest in Texas, named for the pianist Van Cliburn, who won a victory in Moscow at the height of the Cold War.
content: For 17 days, the young artists competed in what some have called the Olympics of piano-playing: the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Texas, one of classical music’s most prestigious contests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Sarah Bahr
title: Paul Haggis Arrested on Sexual Assault Charges in Italy
description: Haggis, who wrote and directed the Oscar-winning crime drama “Crash,” was accused of assaulting a woman in Ostuni over the course of two days.
content: The Oscar-winning director and writer Paul Haggis was arrested on charges of aggravated sexual violence and aggravated personal injuries in the Southern Italian city of Ostuni on Sunday, according to the local police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Ossipov
description: Take on Ossipov in a recreation of a Tuesday Night Marathon game in San Francisco, 2006. Solve for the best series of moves.
content: About Daniel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Republican Drive to Tilt Courts Against Climate Action Reaches a Crucial Moment
description: A Supreme Court environmental case being decided this month is the product of a coordinated, multiyear strategy by Republican attorneys general and conservative allies.
content: WASHINGTON — Within days, the conservative majority on the Supreme Court is expected to hand down a decision that could severely limit the federal government’s authority to reduce carbon dioxide from power plants — pollution that is dangerously heating the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle and Noam Scheiber
title: Apple Workers at Maryland Store Vote to Unionize, a First in the U.S.
description: Roughly two-thirds of employees at the store in Towson, Md., voted to join the union.
content: Apple employees at a Baltimore-area store have voted to unionize, making it the first of the company’s 270-plus stores in the United States to join a trend in labor organizing sweeping through retailers, restaurants and tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: Covid Stopped the Music. Now This School Is Striking Up the Band Again.
description: Young violists and sax players in Brooklyn get reacquainted with their instruments, and with one another: “You have to play in harmony.”
content: Surrounded by classroom walls hung with colorful violins and music theory posters, Roshan Reddy counted to three. He raised his palm, a chorus of shiny horns and woodwinds hummed to life, and the first notes of Adele’s “Easy on Me” filled the band room at P.S. 11 elementary school in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Civil: Ben Crump’ Review: What Becomes of a Missed Opportunity?
description: The documentary “Civil” follows Ben Crump, the prominent attorney who has represented families affected by police violence, for one turbulent year.
content: At the beginning of “Civil” — a documentary about the civil-rights attorney Ben Crump — a phone call from Tera Brown, a cousin of George Floyd, comes into Crump’s office. Crump listens compassionately as Brown relates the 2020 murder of her cousin by a Minneapolis police officer. Crump gently offers her some advice about next steps, then rests his head in his hands. The image of Crump holding his own head, and of Crump rubbing his eyes, is repeated throughout “Civil.” It is the weary physical response to ongoing injustice and to a schedule that keeps the lawyer on planes and on his smartphone, pursuing lawsuits intended to make police departments and municipalities pay financially — and the media and the court of public opinion pay heed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Heat Wave to Shift East After Posing Dangerous Conditions in the Plains
description: More than 15 million people in the Northern and Central Plains were under heat alerts on Sunday, the National Weather Service said.
content: Heat continues to build in the Northern and Central Plains of the United States, with more than 15 million people there under heat alerts on Sunday. Temperatures in Minnesota and Nebraska were expected to climb to the triple digits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky
title: Ataques, rumores y acusaciones en una contienda muy reñida por la presidencia
description: Los dos candidatos que compiten para ser el próximo presidente de Colombia —Gustavo Petro, un izquierdista y ex insurgente, y Rodolfo Hernández, un próspero empresario— no son conocidos por andarse con rodeos.
content: Los dos candidatos que compiten para ser el próximo presidente de Colombia —Gustavo Petro, un izquierdista y ex insurgente, y Rodolfo Hernández, un próspero empresario— no son conocidos por andarse con rodeos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Looming over the election is the rise of armed groups that threaten to once again tear Colombia apart.
description: Colombia’s peace accord, signed in 2016 by the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, was supposed to usher in a new era of peace in a nation that had endured more than five decades of war. The deal was that the rebels would lay down their arms, while the government would flood conflict zones with job opportunities, alleviating the poverty and inequality that had started the war.
content: Colombia’s peace accord, signed in 2016 by the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, was supposed to usher in a new era of peace in a nation that had endured more than five decades of war. The deal was that the rebels would lay down their arms, while the government would flood conflict zones with job opportunities, alleviating the poverty and inequality that had started the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter May
title: Collin Morikawa Descends Then Climbs the U.S. Open Leaderboard
description: Morikawa shared the lead after the second round and looked poised to vie for his third major championship. A 77 in the third round took him out of contention, but he closed the tournament strong.
content: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Midway through the U.S. Open, Collin Morikawa stood atop the leaderboard looking to add a third major championship to his résumé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
title: It’s Macron vs. the Left in a Fierce Battle for France’s Parliament
description: President Emmanuel Macron’s supporters and an alliance of left-wing parties came in neck and neck in the first round of voting. Now they are in a bruising face-off for control of the lower house of Parliament.
content: Follow our live news updates of France’s parliamentary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nayeema Raza
title: My Father’s Last Gift to Me Came After His Death
description: Only when my father was on his deathbed did I finally realize what he always knew: Obligation doesn’t only take. It gives.
content: As a child, I remember leaving a visit with a great-aunt, my arms folded, eyes rolling and lips in a pout. “That was boring,” I informed my father. “And she’s mean.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: 3 Dead in Wind-Driven Fire in Queens, Officials Say
description: The victims were found in the basement of a house in the Richmond Hill section that was previously cited for an illegal cellar dwelling, records show.
content: At least three people were found dead in a basement after a fire, driven by high winds, swept through several houses in the Richmond Hill section of Queens on Friday, fire officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: As Colombia votes, at stake is the fate of the third largest nation in Latin America.
description: One candidate is Gustavo Petro, a former rebel and longtime senator who is making a bid to become Colombia’s first-ever leftist president, calling for a transformation of the economic system.
content: One candidate is Gustavo Petro, a former rebel and longtime senator who is making a bid to become Colombia’s first-ever leftist president, calling for a transformation of the economic system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: The Fed Goes Big
description: It was a rocky week in the financial markets and for cryto. Elon Musk met with Twitter employees. And there are signs of a slowdown in real estate.
content: In its most  striking move yet to rein in inflation, the Federal Reserve raised its benchmark rate three-quarters of a percentage point Wednesday, the central bank’s biggest increase since 1994. While taking questions from reporters after the announcement, Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said officials were “not trying to induce a recession right now.” Nonetheless, that’s what many fear: If the Fed’s efforts to tame rising prices and tamp down demand go too far, the bank could touch off a serious economic slowdown, forcing businesses to close and sending unemployment numbers back up. And the Fed has shown no signs of changing its path. The increase on Wednesday could be followed by a similarly large one next month. Mr. Powell is likely to face tough questions about this and other Fed actions when he appears before lawmakers in the House and Senate this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Lightyear’ Opens at No. 2, as ‘Jurassic World’ Holds Strong
description: The Pixar movie’s estimated $51 million in North American sales fell short of expectations.
content: Buzz Lightyear failed to reach box office hyperspace over the weekend. But it was unclear why.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Key Hurdle for Prosecutors: Proving What Trump Believed
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 19, 2022.
content: “The problem with Trump is that you have to try to get inside his mind and he has such a history of lying and pushing falsehoods that it makes it difficult to determine what he really believes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: The far right wins a record number of seats.
description: The party of Marine Le Pen secured enough seats to form a parliamentary group, giving it more clout, for the first time in four decades.
content: PARIS — The French far right was projected to win a record number of seats in the election on Sunday, which could make it the third biggest political force in Parliament. It will also secure enough seats to form a parliamentary group for the first time since the 1980s, reflecting its solid political foothold and highlighting the success of Marine Le Pen’s longtime efforts to moderate her party’s image.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
title: Macron Loses Absolute Majority as Opposition Surges, a Blow for New Term
description: For the first time in 20 years, a newly-elected French president failed to win an absolute majority in Parliament, forcing President Macron to deal with a defiant left and a resurgent far-right.
content: PARIS — Voters in France’s legislative elections dealt President Emmanuel Macron a serious blow on Sunday as his centrist coalition lost its absolute majority in the lower house of Parliament to a resurgent far-right and a defiant alliance of left-wing parties, complicating his domestic agenda for his second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Votaciones en Colombia: ‘El país entero está pidiendo un cambio’
description: Dos candidatos con planes de gobierno y formaciones muy distintas se enfrentan el domingo en la segunda vuelta de las elecciones colombianas. Estas son sus principales propuestas.
content: Uno de los candidatos es Gustavo Petro, un exguerrillero y senador con una larga trayectoria que durante mucho tiempo ha tratado de convertirse en el primer presidente de izquierda del país, y propone una transformación del sistema económico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: This Is a Weirder Moment Than You Think
description: Possible U.F.O. sightings, A.I. breakthroughs and the Jan. 6 hearings all help us understand how hard it to grasp what is happening right in front of us.
content: In a recent essay called “How to Future,” Kevin Kelly, one of the founding editors of Wired, writes that “most futurists are really predicting the present. It turns out that the present is very hard to see.” What will upend tomorrow often looks like an aberration, niche, triviality or impossibility today. He goes on to offer advice I’ve been mulling: “I sometimes think of ‘seeing the present’ as trying on alien eyes: looking at the world as if I were an alien from another planet.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was on the M104, and a Woman Was Talking Loudly on Her Phone’
description: Overheard on a Broadway bus, a visit to doughnut heaven and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: How Churches Can Do Better at Responding to Sexual Abuse
description: “We often have a very twisted understanding of authority and unity, and it is wielded in a way that keeps whistle-blowers silent.”
content: In May, a third-party investigation into the Southern Baptist Convention, the largest Protestant denomination in the United States, concluded that some former members of its top leadership committee, along with outside counsel, “closely guarded information about abuse allegations and lawsuits” and “were singularly focused on avoiding liability.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: The Odesa opera house reopens, defying Russia’s aggression.
description: ODESA, Ukraine — In a nation at war, and a city aching for some semblance of normality, the Odesa Opera reopened for the first time since the Russian invasion began, asserting civilization against the barbarism unleashed from Moscow.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — In a nation at war, and a city aching for some semblance of normality, the Odesa Opera reopened for the first time since the Russian invasion began, asserting civilization against the barbarism unleashed from Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 19, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 19, 2022.
content: An article last Sunday about the revival of the roadside franchise Stuckey’s misstated the name of an almond brand. It is Blue Diamond, not Diamond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky
title: Before he was a politician, Gustavo Petro was part of an urban guerrilla group.
description: Petro belonged to M-19, born in 1970 as a response to alleged fraud in that year’s presidential elections. It was far smaller than the country’s main guerrilla force, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.
content: Long before Gustavo Petro emerged as the apparently victorious leftist candidate for president, he was part of the M-19, an urban guerrilla group that sought to seize power through violence in the name of promoting social justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: La presencia de los grupos armados ensombrece las elecciones colombianas
description: Se suponía que el acuerdo de paz de Colombia, firmado en 2016 por el gobierno y las Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia, o FARC, sería el inicio de una nueva era de tranquilidad en un país que soportó más de cinco décadas de conflicto. El acuerdo consistía en que los rebeldes dejaran las armas, mientras que el gobierno inundaba las zonas de conflicto con oportunidades de trabajo, aliviando así la pobreza y la desigualdad que originaron la guerra.
content: Se suponía que el acuerdo de paz de Colombia, firmado en 2016 por el gobierno y las Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia, o FARC, sería el inicio de una nueva era de tranquilidad en un país que soportó más de cinco décadas de conflicto. El acuerdo consistía en que los rebeldes dejaran las armas, mientras que el gobierno inundaba las zonas de conflicto con oportunidades de trabajo, aliviando así la pobreza y la desigualdad que originaron la guerra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky
title: What is Uribismo and why are Colombians voting against it?
description: When Colombia chooses its next president on Sunday, the pivotal election will represent a blow to the country’s dominant political force as voters have become increasingly disillusioned by chronic poverty, inequity and growing insecurity.
content: When Colombia chooses its next president on Sunday, the pivotal election will represent a blow to the country’s dominant political force as voters have become increasingly disillusioned by chronic poverty, inequity and growing insecurity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neelam Bohra
title: Arizona Wildfire Destroys Observatory Buildings
description: The Contreras fire has disrupted the work of astronomers, though the observatory’s scientific equipment remains safe for now.
content: Astronomers watched in fear over the past week as a growing wildfire crept up an Arizona mountainside toward the Kitt Peak National Observatory, forcing 40 people to evacuate days before the blaze destroyed four buildings early Friday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Children of Ukraine’s fallen soldiers spend Father’s Day in new grief.
description: As the war’s death toll continues to climb, families mourn the losses of fathers-turned-soldiers.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — In the heat of the late afternoon sun, Oksana Stepanenko’s sweat mingled with the tears streaming down her face as she rearranged the flowers on her husband’s grave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Western leaders warn that the war in Ukraine could last years.
description: Jens Stoltenberg said that Ukrainian forces were fighting bravely, and that with the arrival of more modern weaponry, they would be able to push Russian troops out of the eastern Donbas region.
content: Two senior Western leaders have renewed warnings that the war in Ukraine could last years, and that the country’s allies should prepare to support it in a lengthy fight against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Shih
title: How I Became an Asian American
description: The killing of a Chinese American, Vincent Chin, 40 years ago changed the way people of Asian descent began to see themselves.
content: In 1993, I was preparing to move to Ann Arbor, Mich., for graduate school when a friend, a Korean American, gave me a few words of advice:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Zelensky visits war-torn Mykolaiv and Odesa in southern Ukraine.
description: LVIV, Ukraine — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Saturday morning made an unannounced visit to Mykolaiv, a southern Ukrainian city battered by the war that has been held up by Kyiv as a sign of fierce resistance, and the nearby port city of Odesa.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Saturday morning made an unannounced visit to Mykolaiv, a southern Ukrainian city battered by the war that has been held up by Kyiv as a sign of fierce resistance, and the nearby port city of Odesa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Loopholes and Missing Data: The Gaps in the Gun Background Check System
description: The massive system already has major loopholes advocated by gun manufacturers to maintain easier access to firearms. The Senate’s proposed gun reform measures could fall victim to those same limitations.
content: The bipartisan gun control bill being hashed out in the Senate this weekend leans heavily on a muscular but mistake-plagued bureaucratic workhorse familiar to any American who has bought a firearm recently: the federal background check system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: A Looming Threat
description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has civilians in Taiwan taking China’s aggression more seriously.
content: Taiwan has spent more than seven decades under the threat of an invasion: China sees the island as a breakaway part of its territory. In the months since Russia invaded Ukraine, Taiwanese citizens have come to view a Chinese incursion as a more serious possibility than ever. My colleague Amy Qin, who’s based in Taipei, Taiwan’s capital, recently reported on how the island is preparing. I called her to learn more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Establishment conservatives quickly aligned with Hernández after his unexpected second-place win.
description: “Today the country of politicking and corruption lost,” Rodolfo Hernández, a right-wing anti-establishment candidate, said in a video message to his supporters, following the first-round election results in May that put him in second place behind Gustavo Petro.
content: “Today the country of politicking and corruption lost,” Rodolfo Hernández, a right-wing anti-establishment candidate, said in a video message to his supporters, following the first-round election results in May that put him in second place behind Gustavo Petro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: ‘The Ordering of Moses’ Shines at Riverside Church
description: The Harlem Chamber Players presented R. Nathaniel Dett’s 1937 oratorio in honor of the centennial of the Harlem Renaissance, for the Juneteenth weekend.
content: The Harlem Chamber Players offered a rare, heartfelt performance of R. Nathaniel Dett’s 1937 oratorio “The Ordering of Moses” at Riverside Church on Friday, as part of a centennial celebration of the Harlem Renaissance that had been delayed by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: You’re Still on Mute
description: Hybrid or remote work is settling in as a permanent reality for millions. Their setups and technical skills can still feel like a temporary solution.
content: It’s been almost 28 months since offices shut down and millions of people started working from home. More than enough time to buy a ring light, hang some art on the walls and figure out the mute button. But as is clear to Claude Taylor, co-creator of the Twitter account Room Rater, which scores video call backgrounds, that is not what has happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: Sure, Just Have the Baby
description: There are good reasons American women overwhelmingly choose having an abortion over giving up a child for adoption.
content: There’s a lot I don’t remember about giving birth to my first child. But I do remember 24 hours of back labor followed by two hours of pushing to no avail. I remember, through a high fever and the agony of exertion, my body shaking with hard chills when I heard the doctor say the words “emergency C-section.” I remember feeling a scalpel run along my midsection and screaming “Yes!” when asked if I was in pain and then “No” when asked if I would like to see my baby. No way did I want to meet my child for the first time under these circumstances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Over 200 Feared Dead in Ethiopia Massacre
description: The killings were the latest to roil the Horn of Africa nation, which is reeling from a civil war that began almost two years ago.
content: KIGALI, Rwanda — An Ethiopian rebel group massacred more than 200 members of the Amhara ethnic group on Sunday, according to officials and news reports, the latest atrocity amid a civil war that threatens to tear apart Africa’s second-most-populous nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: The ‘Hard Yakka’ of Defining Australian English’s Many Quirks
description: It took a while for Australians to appreciate their linguistic distinctiveness. The editors at the Australian National Dictionary Center work to document it.
content: CANBERRA, Australia — Amanda Laugesen scrolled through the spreadsheet of 7,000 words and idioms being considered for the next edition of the Australian National Dictionary, but no matter how hard she looked, she just couldn’t find the phrase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky
title: Antes de dedicarse a la política, Petro formó parte de una guerrilla urbana
description: Gustavo Petro perteneció al M-19, surgido en 1970 en respuesta a un supuesto fraude en las elecciones presidenciales de ese año. Era más pequeño que la principal fuerza guerrillera del país, las FARC.
content: Mucho antes de que Gustavo Petro surgiera como un candidato de izquierda a la presidencia de Colombia, fue parte del M-19, un grupo guerrillero urbano que buscaba hacerse del poder en nombre de la justicia social.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandeep Jauhar
title: Facing Death During the Pandemic
description: Marie Brenner’s “The Desperate Hours” looks at how health care workers dealt with the perils of Covid.
content: The ethics manual of the American College of Physicians states that “the ethical imperative for physicians to provide care” overrides “the risk to the treating physician, even during epidemics.” Nevertheless, for most of human history, doctors often ran away in the face of widespread contagious disease. During a yellow fever epidemic in Philadelphia in 1793, many distinguished physicians fled the city. More recently, health workers abandoned patients during an Ebola epidemic in the Democratic Republic of Congo in 1995, as well as during a SARS outbreak in Toronto in 2003.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany will fire up coal plants again in an effort to save natural gas.
description: It was one of a series of measures announced by Germany’s economy minister, as Europe takes steps to deal with reduced energy supplies from Russia.
content: BERLIN — Germany will restart coal-fired power plants in order to conserve natural gas, the country’s economy minister announced on Sunday, amid concerns about a looming supply shortage after Russia cut gas deliveries to Europe this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Beginnerish
description: Christopher Youngs’s puzzle is a good place for a newbie to start solving.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, Wordplay readers! Today we have a puzzle from Christopher Youngs, less than a month after his last appearance, that is sure to please demographers and baseball fans alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: FINA Restricts Transgender Women From Competing at Elite Level
description: The international swimming federation said transgender women who had experienced male puberty could not compete in women’s events.
content: The world governing body for swimming effectively barred transgender women from the highest levels of women’s international competition on Sunday, intensifying a debate over gender and sports that has roiled state legislatures and increasingly divided parents, athletes and coaches at all levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Not All Champions Become Dynasties. Here’s Why Golden State Did.
description: Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Draymond Green won four N.B.A. championship teams in eight years.
content: BOSTON — The N.B.A.’s dynasties share certain commonalities that have helped them tip the scales from being run-of-the-mill championship teams to those remembered for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Vivian Yee, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak
title: Russian Forces Tighten Noose Around Important Cities in Ukraine’s East
description: The area around Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk is about three-quarters encircled by Russians, leaving only a slender gap there for Ukrainian troops to maneuver.
content: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — Russian forces appeared poised to tighten the noose around thousands of Ukrainian troops near two strategically important cities in the fiercely contested Donbas region of eastern Ukraine on Sunday, mounting an assault on Ukrainian front lines that forced Ukraine to rush reinforcements to the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Drake Rebuilt Hip-Hop in His Image. Now He Wants You to Dance.
description: On his seventh album, “Honestly, Nevermind,” the pop disrupter who rethought rap’s relationship with melody opts for a new direction: nightclub abandon.
content: For more than a decade, the Drake factory has been operating at full capacity — recalibrating the relationship between hip-hop, R&B and pop; balancing grand-scale ambition with granular experimentation; embracing the meme-ification of his celebrity. But in recent years, for the first time, it’s felt like the machines might be grinding to a pause. Maintaining the throne is hard work, and the wear and tear were beginning to show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Nutcrackers, Sadism and Accounting
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello, readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russia’s advances in eastern Ukraine have been costly.
description: It has been two months since the Kremlin began its large-scale assault on the eastern Donbas region of Ukraine, directing the force of its vast arsenal along a 300-mile front and inflicting heavy losses on Ukrainian forces as its fighters blasted their way to grueling gains.
content: It has been two months since the Kremlin began its large-scale assault on the eastern Donbas region of Ukraine, directing the force of its vast arsenal along a 300-mile front and inflicting heavy losses on Ukrainian forces as its fighters blasted their way to grueling gains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At U.S. Open, Matt Fitzpatrick’s First PGA Tour Win Comes at a Major
description: Will Zalatoris and Scottie Scheffler, who tied for second, made it interesting down the stretch at the Country Club, but Fitzpatrick held on to finish at six under par.
content: BROOKLINE, Mass. — This year’s U.S. Open began as the setting for an unprecedented showdown between golfers who had remained loyal to the established PGA Tour and a breakaway pack of ex-colleagues who recently joined the new, rebel Saudi-backed LIV Golf series. But the anticipated confrontation at the Country Club outside Boston fizzled in the first round on Thursday when golfers from both camps got along without friction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aida Alami
title: Saving Historic Songs, and a Jewish Culture in Morocco
description: For centuries after the expulsion from Spain, Morocco’s Sephardic Jewish women sang of love, loss and identity. Now, they’re almost all gone.
content: TANGIER, Morocco — They sang to put their babies to sleep, or in the kitchen preparing Purim cakes. They sang in courtyards at night when the men were at synagogue for evening prayer, songs of love, loss, religion and war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Makes Slow Gains in the Donbas Region
description: Also, France’s president lost a majority in Parliament and Colombians voted for their next leader.
content: Russian forces mounted an assault on Sunday against Toshkivka, a key Ukrainian defensive position near Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, highlighting Ukraine’s faltering defense of two of the last cities in the Luhansk province of the Donbas region that are not yet under Russian control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Gerald
title: The True Meaning of Juneteenth
description: That June 19 in 1865, the day we now celebrate as a nation, was the day that Black Texans officially received some of the stalest news in American history.
content: I won’t pretend Juneteenth has always meant a lot to me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: A Queen in Any Other Language
description: The history of how the queen became the most powerful piece in chess.
content: The queen is known as the most powerful piece on the chess board, so the prospect of sacrificing it invokes an unparalleled excitement among chess enthusiasts. There is something inherently satisfying about giving up the strongest piece on the board in order to checkmate the enemy king. I hope that this week’s puzzles served as a worthy reminder that all of us — beginners and grandmasters alike — can unite around an appreciation of the unique, almost otherworldly beauty of the royal game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky
title: As the Colombian presidential race tightens, the two candidates turn up their attacks.
description: The two candidates competing to become Colombia’s next president — Gustavo Petro, a leftist and a former insurgent, and Rodolfo Hernández, a wealthy businessman — are not known for pulling punches.
content: The two candidates competing to become Colombia’s next president — Gustavo Petro, a leftist and a former insurgent, and Rodolfo Hernández, a wealthy businessman — are not known for pulling punches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Ivory, John Ismay, Denise Lu, Marco Hernandez, Cierra S. Queen, Jess Ruderman, Kristine White, Lauryn Higgins and Bonnie G. Wong
title: What Hundreds of Photos of Weapons Reveal About Russia’s Brutal War Strategy
description: A New York Times analysis of visual evidence from Ukraine showed widespread use by Russia of cluster weapons banned under certain international treaties.
content: A New York Times analysis of visual evidence from Ukraine showed widespread use by Russia of cluster weapons banned under certain international treaties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Peanut butter-glazed salmon, chicken Caprese, fried egg quesadillas and more recipes to make very soon.
content: Good morning. I had some wild salmon thawing in the refrigerator and was all set for Sunday supper: peanut butter-glazed salmon and green beans (above). Peanut butter is a smart shortcut ingredient, used to anchor the savory five-ingredient sauce. But then a neighbor stopped by with some tuna he’d caught 55 miles off Brooklyn in the blazing sun: a couple of collars, some loin, some scrapings for tuna tartare. I thanked him and came up with a new plan. (But you should make that salmon tonight.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transgender Women in the Sports World
description: The debate over whether they have physical advantages that make athletic competitions unfair. Also: Homeowners’ rights; marriages, happy and not.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
